record.text: Andrew Cuomo with the state Senate is probably an example of the broader argument. From redistricting to encouraging a bipartisan coalition after dems won, he actively worked to prop up the opposition.
She will possibly be in a more competitive district in 2024, thanks to GOP redistricting. Watching her voting record shift accordingly will be sad.

Thanks, signed 75% of America and 99% of the world 🌎✅💙

value.text: Without the rejection of Hochul nominee Hector LaSalle, the responsibility for drawing new congressional districts in the state could very well have stayed in the hands of its court system. hellgatenyc.com/thank-progre...

record.text: In fact, the Independent Bipartisan Redistricting Commission in New York failed to produce a map, so the legislature created one, and a judge threw it out and ordered a special master to draw one, which isn’t what the state Constitution says should happen. The Commission must do its job.

images.alt: @RpsAgainstTrump: "NEW: By a four-to-three vote, New York's high court ruled today that the state must redraw congressional maps. This ruling could help Democrats gain as many as 6 House seats."

value.text:
Great news!🎉 The San Francisco Elections Commission unanimously voted to pass its redistricting reform recommendations (one commissioner was absent). The final recommendations will be sent to the supervisors and shared with the public in the new year.

If you contacted the commission, THANK YOU!

record.text:
NY's highest court orders bipartisan redistricting commission to redraw congressional map for 2023 elections. The 4-3 ruling favors Democrats, setting a Feb. 28 deadline for compromise. 

More here 👇

If you contacted the commission, THANK YOU!

record.text: This is a very important piece from @yeargain.bsky.social laying out just how screwed up the NY constitution is. If the state's redistricting commission submits dueling maps to the legislature, what happens next is extremely unclear

external.title: What happens if New York’s Independent Redistricting Commission deadlocks again?
external.description: Or, what happens when immovable constitutional ambiguity meets unstoppable partisanship?

external.title: What happens if New York’s Independent Redistricting Commission deadlocks again?
external.description: Or, what happens when immovable constitutional ambiguity meets unstoppable partisanship?

record.text: The New York Court of Appeals ruled that the state's "independent" redistricting commission has to try to redraw the state's congressional districts before 2024. Here's what would happen if the IRC fails to do so. (Spoiler: the New York Constitution isn't super clear here.)

external.title: What happens if New York’s Independent Redistricting Commission deadlocks again?
external.description: Or, what happens when immovable constitutional ambiguity meets unstoppable partisanship?

external.title: What happens if New York’s Independent Redistricting Commission deadlocks again?

record.text: I remembered that right after I posted, lol. My lawful good side says that's how ALL redistricting should be done, but as the GOP uses that against us, it's frustrating.

We will never stop fighting.

The case is one of the latest signs that fights over redistricting will continue. “I don’t expect anybody to lay down arms, not them and certainly not us,” said attorney Abha Khanna, who argued the Alabama case before SCOTUS. www.washingtonpost.com/politics/202...
